title: Should you trust unanimous decisions? - Derek Abbott

multiple-choice.question: What is the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: A concept that suggests that the closer a group comes to total agreement, the more reliable the result becomes.

options.label: B
options.text: A concept that suggests that the closer a group comes to total agreement, the less reliable the result becomes.

options.label: C
options.text: A concept that suggests that the closer a group comes to total disagreement, the more reliable the result becomes.

options.label: D
options.text: A concept that suggests that the closer a group comes to total agreement, the more uncertain the result becomes.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of the paradox of unanimity in a police lineup?

options.label: A
options.text: If six witnesses pick out the same person, it's likely that the person is guilty.

options.label: B
options.text: If all ten witnesses make the same choice, it's likely that the person is guilty.

options.label: C
options.text: If six witnesses pick out the same person, it's likely that there's a systemic error or bias in the lineup.

options.label: D
options.text: If all ten witnesses make the same choice, it's likely that the person is not guilty.

options.label: C
options.text: A study conducted by a university.

options.label: D
options.text: A study conducted by a private company.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A study that found up to 48% of witnesses tend to pick the wrong person out of a lineup.

options.label: D
options.text: A case where DNA evidence was contaminated due to factory errors.

options.label: C
options.text: The level of uncertainty involved in a situation.

options.label: D
options.text: The level of reliability of a result.

options.label: A
options.text: A case where DNA evidence was contaminated due to factory errors.

options.label: B
options.text: A study that found up to 48% of witnesses tend to pick the wrong person out of a lineup.

options.label: C
options.text: A presidential referendum held by Saddam Hussein in 2002.

options.label: D
options.text: A police lineup where witnesses are asked to identify a bank robber.

options.text: That it is caused by our desires.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is caused by external circumstances.

options.text: That it is not a part of the human condition.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A path that allows for no concentration on cultivating compassion for others and seeking enlightenment.

options.label: D
options.text: A path that allows for excessive concentration on cultivating compassion for others and seeking enlightenment.

multiple-choice.question: What are the four noble truths?

options.label: A
options.text: The realisation that suffering is a part of the human condition, that it is caused by our desires, that we can transcend it by removing or managing these desires, and that we can learn to move beyond suffering through the noble eightfold path.

options.label: B
options.text: The realisation that suffering is not a part of the human condition, that it is caused by external circumstances, that we can transcend it by avoiding these circumstances, and that we can learn to move beyond suffering through the noble eightfold path.

options.label: C
options.text: The realisation that suffering is a part of the human condition, that it is caused by our lack of desires, that we can transcend it by increasing our desires, and that we can learn to move beyond suffering through the noble eightfold path.

options.label: D
options.text: The realisation that suffering is not a part of the human condition, that it is caused by our desires, that we can transcend it by removing or managing these desires, and that we can learn to move beyond suffering through the noble eightfold path.

multiple-choice.question: What is the noble eightfold path?

options.label: A
options.text: A series of aspects of behaving "right" and wisely.

options.label: B
options.text: A series of aspects of behaving "wrong" and unwise.

options.label: C
options.text: A series of aspects of behaving randomly and without consideration.

options.label: D
options.text: A series of aspects of behaving excessively and without moderation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of following the noble eightfold path?

options.label: A
options.text: We can learn to move beyond suffering.

options.label: B
options.text: We can learn to avoid suffering.

options.label: C
options.text: We can learn to increase our desires.

options.label: D
options.text: We can learn to decrease our compassion.
